intro: Veronica subsessilis var. subintegra, commonly known as the narrow-leaved speedwell, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 10–30 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine, hairy pubescence. The plant produces small, blue or purple flowers in whorled clusters along the stem, which bloom from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, often with a slightly hairy surface, and are arranged alternately along the stem. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and rocky areas.
